Bimetallic catalyst is a major group of the heterogeneous catalysts which has been widely investigated for many important catalytic processes such as biomass upgrading. The synergistic effect between two transition metal of bimetallic catalyst plays a vital role to promote catalytic performance. In this work, the Pd-Mo bimetallic catalysts were investigated for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of a biomass-derived molecule, anisole. The synergistic effect was confirmed in the Pd-Mo bimetallic catalyst. The correlated structure features of the Pd and Mo sites during catalysis have been revealed to understand the synergistic effect. It is found that the Mo species are partially reduced and cover around Pd nanoparticles. As the results, the crystalline status, redox properties, electron state and adsorption behaviors of Pd species are greatly influenced by Mo species. Moreover, the formation of Pd-Mo bond is directly observed by in-situ X-ray absorption spectrum. This work brings new insights to understand the structure origination for the synergistic effect in bimetallic catalyst. Graphical abstract Revealed by in-situ techniques including XAS, the authentic structure of PdMo catalyst under hydrodeoxygenation conditions interprets the how synergistic effect of bimetallic catalyst works. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic effect Bimetallic catalyst Palladium In-situ XAS Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The utilization of renewable energy is a promising solution to the current global environment and energy challenges. Among those renewable energy stocks, biomass is an attractive candidate for its abundance and low cost, which can be converted into fuels and valuable chemicals by catalytic treatment processes [1–4]. The portion of biomass in the global energy consumption has been increasing for a decade and is expected to increase significantly to reduce the carbon dioxide emission. However, biomass stocks need to be catalytically upgraded before it is suitable for application. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a catalytic route to remove the oxygen content in the biomass-derived molecules and further produce valuable chemicals, which has attracted lots of attentions in recent decades [2,5]. In general, a desired HDO catalyst requires two sets of catalytic sites for hydrogen dissociation and C-O bond cleavage, respectively. Therefore, many efforts have been dedicated to the rational catalyst design for HDO catalyst such as metal-acid catalyst and bimetallic catalyst [6,7]. Bimetallic catalyst represents a major catalog of catalyst for heterogeneous catalysis [8]. The combination of two distinct transition metal provides great potential for catalysis due to the tunable electronic state and surface structure of bimetallic catalyst. Consequently, the bimetallic catalyst has been studied from the fundamental study to application [9–12]. Resasco et al. reported that the NiMo bimetallic catalyst had high activity and high selectivity for HDO reaction. The reason was that the Ni core was modified by MoOx after reduction, which realized the synergistic effect of Ni and Mo [13]. O'Hare et al. immobilized palladium and ultrafine molybdenum phosphate nanoparticles on silica, in which Pd and the acidic site could not only catalyze the HDO reaction efficiently, but also have a strong regeneration capacity [14]. Supported bimetallic catalysts for HDO reaction are usually consisted of one noble metal and another non-noble metal [15]. The intrinsic mechanism for the synergy between two catalytic sites is the key to understand the structure-catalytic correlation of the catalyst [16,17]. It has been proposed that the noble metals are generally active sites and the non-noble metals interact with the noble metals to change the surface properties which improves catalytic activity and modifies the selectivity to the desired product [18–20]. For example, Wang et al. explored the mechanism of Pd/Fe2O3 for the synergistic effect of HDO reaction. It was suggested that Fe0 was the active site of HDO, while Pd mainly contributes to the activation of H2, stabilization of the reduced state of Fe0, and promotion of the desorption of the product toluene [21]. Lee et al. studied the synergistic effect on Pd/WOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. It was proposed that the physicochemical state of Pd and the surface acidity determined the HDO activity. The interaction between tungstate and Pd not only affected the state of Pd but also affected the surface acidity. Thus, the synergistic effect of bimetallic catalysts significantly impacted on HDO [21]. However, the study on the correlation between authentic structure of catalyst during reaction and the synergistic effect is still lacking. In this work, we investigated a series of catalysts including Pd/SiO2, Mo/SiO2 and bimetallic catalyst PdMo/SiO2 as the model catalysts. They are tested for catalytically HDO of anisole at a relatively low temperature range of 150-250 °C. A distinct synergistic effect between Pd and Mo is confirmed in the different performance in HDO of anisole. Then, comprehensive characterizations were performed to study the authentic structure of catalytic sites during reaction and how the structure of the catalysts were related with the catalytic performance. Furthermore, integrated in-situ studies, featured by in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, were performed to understand the authentic structure of catalytic sites correlated with the synergistic effect in the HDO reaction. It is found that the crystalline structure, redox properties, electron state and adsorption behaviors of Pd are greatly influenced by Mo species. Moreover, the formation of Pd-Mo bond is directly observed. The Mo species are partially reduced and cover around Pd sites, which not only changes the electronic state of Pd sites, but also harnessing the adsorption behavior of molecules on Pd sites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The chemicals including SiO2, Pd(NO)3, H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O were used as received for the preparation of the supported catalysts. Silica gel (SiO2, AS ONE International, Q50, 99% AR) was used as the support. Pd/SiO2 and Mo/SiO2 catalysts were prepared with an incipient-wetness method using an aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 (Aldrich AR, 99%) to prepare 0.5 wt% of Pd or an aqueous solution of H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O (Macklin AR, 99%) to prepare 0.5 wt% of Mo on SiO2 support. After impregnation, the samples were dried at 80 °C overnight and then calcined at 350 °C for 3 h. For the PdMo/SiO2 catalysts, Pd and Mo were impregnated by two steps, 0.5 wt% of palladium was impregnated by an incipient wetness with an aqueous solution of Pd (NO3)2 on the Mo/SiO2 catalyst. Then, the sample was dried at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 350 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts X-Ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on an Ultimate III diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å). The diffraction patterns were collected in a 2-theta range of 5-90 ° at a scanning rate of 5 °/min. High Resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images for Pd/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 were obtained using an FEI Talos F200S G2 (FEI, USA). The catalysts were reduced by H2 at 250 °C for 30 min before TEM analysis. In a typical sample preparation, 10 mg of the sample was grounded to fine powder and dispersed in 50 mL anhydrous ethanol by ultrasonic. The ethanol dispersion was added dropwise to the copper grid with carbon lacey film. The sample was examined by TEM after being dried naturally. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured on an ASAP 2020 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) by N2 adsorption method. The samples were degassed at 200 °C and measured at 77.35 K. Temperature-programmed reduction in flowing H2 (AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer, Micromeritics, USA) was used to explore the reducibility of the samples. Each sample was pre-treated through heating at 300 °C for 1 h under He flow, and then tested with the temperature from 50 °C to 700 °C (10 °C/min) with a flow of 10% H2/Ar gas. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectrometer (Thermal-Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (200 W, E=1486.6 eV). All samples were reduced by H2 at 250 °C for 30 min before testing. The binding energy of all samples was calibrated to Si 2p peak at 103.5 eV. The Diffuse Reflectance Fourier Transform (DRIFT) spectra of CO adsorption of the samples were obtained on Nicolet iS50 spectrometer (Thermal-Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with a praying mantis in-situ reaction cell (Harrick Scientific Instrument, USA). For CO adsorption, first the samples were heated at 250 °C for 30 min in H2 (20 mL/min) and Ar (20 mL/min), then cooled to 25 °C for background collection. After the 10% CO/Ar gas (20 mL/min) was flowed into the cell for CO adsorption until saturation, it was purged with Ar and the measurement was performed until no change in the spectrum was observed. The Raman spectra of all samples were collected by DXR2xi microscope spectrometer (Thermal-Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with 532 nm laser excitations. The authentic amount of Pd and Mo in the catalysts were measured by ICP-OES (iCAP 7000 SERIES, Thermal-Fisher Scientific, USA). The standard solution of Pd and Mo were measured to set up the standing curves. Then, the metal in the catalyst was dissolved in aqua regia and diluted for measurement. The UV-Visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy was performed by Cary 5000 UV-Vis instrument (Varian, USA) using BaSO4 substrate as a reference. Samples were taken in the sample cell and scanned at 200-800 nm. X-ray absorption experiment was performed at BL-36XU, Spring-8, Japan. The incident X-ray was tuned by a set of Si (311) double crystal monochromator. The photon energy was calibrated by a piece of Pd or Mo foil. The spectra of Mo K edge and Pd K edge were collected under fluorescence mode with a Ge solid state detector. For the in-situ XAS experiment, the catalyst powder was loaded in a capillary quartz tube and then mounted on an in-situ cell [22]. The flow rate of the gaseous reactant was controlled by a mass flow reactor. The anisole vapor was purged into the cell by a bubbling bottle. The catalyst was kept at desired temperature and reactive atmosphere for half hour before data collection. Multiple data scans were collected under each condition. The data was processed and analyzed by Demeter Software package [23]. The Rbkg is 1.25 and 1.0 for Mo and Pd K edge, respectively. The data in the k range of 3.5-13.5 Å−1 and the R range of 1.25-3.4 Å was used for data fitting for Fourier transformed EXAFS data. The wavelet transformation of EXAFS data was performed with HAMA Fortran package [24,25]. The wavelet transformation parameters: κ=10, σ=1, Morlet function. 2.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts in the HDO reaction was evaluated in a fixed-bed catalytic reactor. The anisole vapour was purged into the reactor by flowing H2 through a bubbling bottle under atmosphere pressure. The anisole vapor in the reactant gas feed is estimated by Antoine Equation from NIST database. In a typical HDO activity test, 0.05 g fresh catalyst was used and the reactions were carried out at 150 °C, 200 °C and 250 °C; the H2 flow was 4 mL/min and the anisole vapour flow was 0.08 mL/min (T=25 °C). Before reaction, the catalysts were charged in the reactor and reduced by H2 with 16 mL/min at 150 °C for 30 min. The reaction products were analysed by GC-2014 (Shimazu, Japan), using a Rt-Stabilwax-DA column (0.53 mm × 1 µm × 60 m) and a flame-ionization detector (FID). The product yield and selectivity for each product were calculated as follow. C o n v e r s i o n a n i s o l e ( % ) = N a n i s o l e , i n − N a n i s o l e , o u t N a n i s o l e , i n × 100 Conversion anisole (%) -Conversion of anisole; N anisole, in-mol of anisole in pristine mixed gas; N anisole, out- mol of anisole in exit gas S e l e c t i v i t y H D O ( % ) = ∑ H D O N N a n i s o l e , i n − N a n i s o l e , o u t × 100 Selectivity HDO - Selectivity of HDO products; ∑N HDO- the sum mol of the HDO products. The primary HDO products is benzene. The secondary HDO product is cyclohexane. For example, the ratio of benzene to cyclohexane at 250 °C is 12.1. S e l e c t i v i t y H Y D ( % ) = ∑ H Y D N N a n i s o l e , i n − N a n i s o l e , o u t × 100 Selectivity HYD - Selectivity of hydrogenation products; ∑NHYD- the sum mol of the HYD products. The hydrogenation product found in this work is methoxylcyclohexane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synergistic effect of PdMo catalyst in HDO reaction HDO of biomass-derived molecules have been widely investigated on the model compounds containing aryl ring and methyl oxygen group, such as phenol, anisole, cresol and et al. [5]. In this work, anisole was chosen as a representative bio-oil molecules and investigated for the HDO activities with a series of PdMo catalysts. Silica (SiO2) was chosen as the support for Pd and Mo for the relative weak interaction between supported metal and SiO2. Therefore, the interaction between Pd and Mo could be focused in this research. Three catalysts, Pd/SiO2, Mo/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 were prepared and evaluated for the catalytic performance at the temperature range of 150-250 °C, which is a relative low temperature compared with HDO conditions in literatures [26]. The conversion of anisole and the selectivity to HDO products are summarized in Fig. 1 . In the control experiment of the Pd/SiO2 catalyst, the conversion increases from 96% to 98% with the temperature increasing from 150 °C to 200 °C (Fig. 1a). However, the conversion decreases to 52% with the further increase of temperature to 250 °C, which is due to the rapid deactivation of the catalyst. It's also noticed that the major product is hydrogenation product rather than HDO product as shown by the blue line/point in Fig. 1a. Therefore, the hydrogenation (HYD) pathway is favored on Pd/SiO2 catalyst. In other words, the oxygen atoms are not removed from anisole successfully by Pd/SiO2 catalyst. As a contrast, the Mo/SiO2 catalyst shows very low conversion (Fig. 1b). Thus, the conversion of anisole on the Pd/SiO2 catalyst is good but the selectivity to HDO product is poor, the catalyst easily deactivates upon elevated temperature, while the supported molybdenum oxide alone does not present catalytic activity. However, in the case of both Pd and Mo are supported on SiO2, the activity of PdMo/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst is very different from the monometallic supported palladium or molybdenum catalysts (Fig. 1c). With the increase of temperature from 150 °C to 250 °C, it is found not only the conversion of anisole on PdMo/SiO2 catalyst increases from 17% to 90%, but also the selectivity of HDO increases from 72% to 99%. The selectivity to hydrogenation product is less than 5% at 250 °C. The enhanced stability of the PdMo catalyst is also evaluated on the time of stream as shown in Fig. S1. Comparing the HDO activity of the three groups of catalysts, it is found that there is a synergistic effect between palladium and molybdenum, which leads to enhanced HDO conversion and selectivity of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. The synergistic effect is further confirmed by the control experiment of the physical mixture of Pd/SiO2 and Mo/SiO2, which fails to show the promoted HDO activity (Fig. 1d). Therefore, the interaction between Pd and Mo plays on crucial role for the HDO catalytic performance. As shown by the data in Table S1, the authentic loading amounts of Pd and (or) Mo in the catalysts were quantified by ICP-OES method. The Pd and Mo is found to be 0.36 and 0.42 wt.%, respectively in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. The value is consistent to the value found in Pd/SiO2 (0.30 wt.% Pd) and Mo/SiO2 (0.47 wt.% Mo) catalyst, respectively. Therefore, the exhibited distinct catalytic performance is not due to the difference in Pd or Mo contents. In last decades, it has been realized that the catalyst would undergo restructuring (structure change) at atomic level under reactive condition in response to the total surface Gibbs free energy change due to the temperature, pressure and chemical potential of the molecules in the gas phase and the adsorbates [27–31]. Therefore, we consider the correlation of the nanostructure of the catalyst to the HDO activity is one of the main goals of this work. The key is to resolve the authentic structure of the catalyst at the best working condition(s). In the current presented data, the best activity is observed at 250 °C as shown in Fig. 1c. Thus, the critical structure of the catalyst should be the structure formed, or maintained at 250 °C under HDO reactive condition, which is the focus of the following investigations. In summary, the catalytic enhanced performance of the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst confirms the synergistic effect in HDO, and further provide itself as a model catalyst to be investigated fundamentally in following study. 3.2 Catalyst structure and properties of bimetallic catalyst The structure of the catalysts was firstly examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) as shown in Fig. 2 . The Pd/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 catalysts demonstrate metallic particles (marked in yellow circles). The lattice fringes of metallic particle on the Pd/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 catalyst were estimated to be 2.2 Å, which was attributed to (111) crystal plane of metallic Pd. In addition, the images in Figs. S2 and 3 show the element distribution of Pd and Mo on SiO2. For Pd/SiO2 (Fig. S2) and PdMo/SiO2 (Fig. S3) catalyst, the TEM images clearly confirm a similar distribution of for Pd on the catalysts. The Pd species aggregated to form nanoparticles, while Mo dispersed uniformly in the catalyst. All samples including the fresh catalysts and the catalysts reduced by H2 were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) as shown in Fig. S4. One broad peak at 21.9 ° is found in fresh catalysts and after reduction, which is assigned to the amorphous SiO2 [32]. In addition, no diffraction peak for Pd or Mo was observed in the fresh catalyst, indicating that the metals are highly dispersed on SiO2. Moreover, a weak diffraction peak at 40.1 ° is found only in the case of reduced Pd/SiO2. It is due to the formation of metallic palladium (PDF No. 46-1043), which is consistent with TEM images in Fig. 2a. However, the peak of metallic Pd is not found in PdMo/SiO2 sample, which may due to the crystalline structure of Pd nanoparticle is relatively poor in PdMo/SiO2. Thus, the XRD results indicate that Pd was feasibly reduced to the metallic Pd particles in Pd/SiO2 catalyst under reaction conditions. This conclusion is consistent with TPR result in the following. In order to reveal the surface properties of the catalysts, results of physical adsorption of nitrogen are summarized in Table S2 and Fig. S5. All samples show a type-IV isotherm of mesoporous structure. The surface areas of the three samples obtained from BET method are similar to that of the primitive SiO2 support. This is due to the supported metal Pd and/or Mo do(es) not change the surface structure and properties of SiO2, which is consistent with the TEM and XRD data. The surface redox property was investigated by temperature-programmed reduction. The reduction profiles are summarized in Fig. S6. For the Mo/SiO2 catalyst, a weak reduction peak for molybdenum is found at 193 °C, suggesting reduction of Mo6+ species to lower oxidation state (Mo4+). In the H2-TPR profiles of Pd/SiO2 catalysts, a reduction signal at 76 °C is observed. The obvious reduction peak is at lower temperature (<100 °C), which was caused by the reduction of Pd [33]. The bimetallic catalyst PdMo/SiO2 shows similar reduction behaviors compared with Pd/SiO2 and Mo/SiO2. Notably, the first peak at 70 °C is attributed to the reduction to form Pd0, while the 2nd peak at 188 °C is assigned to the reduction from Mo6+ to Mo4+. The downshifts of reduction temperature are obvious fingerprint for a direct interaction between Pd and Mo [34,35]. Additionally, the normalized peak area of Pd reduction peak for PdMo/SiO2 is only 5.8 mmol/g, which is about half of that of Pd/SiO2 (11.8 mmol/g, Table S3), which is ascribed to molybdenum may partially cover palladium in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. Combined with the XRD (Fig. S4) and the TEM images (Fig. 2), It is assumed that the addition of molybdenum contributes to the lower reduction temperature of Pd in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. The surface chemical state of three catalysts was evaluated by XPS in Fig. 3 . The photoemission feature of Mo 3d of the Mo/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3a. The Mo 3d spectrum is splitted to a pair of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 doublet. For the PdMo/SiO2 sample, The Mo 3d spectrum is deconvoluted to two pairs components which the 3d5/2 are at 228.0 eV and 232.8 eV. These are characteristic of the Mo4+ and Mo6+, respectively [26,36–38]. The appearance of Mo4+ suggested the MoO3 was partially reduced by H2 [39], which agrees well with the TPR result. On the other hand, the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 spin-orbit doublet was found in the spectra analyses (Fig. 3b). In the case of PdMo/SiO2, deconvolution of the Pd 3d signal leads to only one component centered at 335.7 eV associated to metallic Pd0 phase [21]. The Pd 3d5/2 spectrum for the Pd/SiO2 catalyst exhibits one peak (335.6 eV) ascribed to Pd0 [40]. A slightly charge transfer from Pd to Mo is observed in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. The Mo 3d5/2 of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is 232.8 eV, which is 0.1 eV lower than that of Mo/SiO2 catalyst. It suggests the electron density of the Mo in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is slightly higher than that of Mo in Mo/SiO2. On the other side, the Pd 3d5/2 of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is 335.7 eV, which is 0.1 eV higher than that of Pd/SiO2. Thus, the electron density of Pd in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is slightly lower than that of Pd/SiO2. Above results hint the electron transfer from Pd to Mo in the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. In addition, surface atomic ratio was evaluated by the XPS peak area and the atomic sensitive factors as listed in Table S4 [38]. The surface Pd/Si and Mo/Si molar ratios derived from XPS of PdMo/SiO2 were obviously higher than the value of Pd/SiO2 or Mo/SiO2, identifying the enhanced dispersion of Pd and Mo species on the surface of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. Besides, the surface atomic ratio of Pd to Mo obtained from XPS in PdMo/SiO2 is 0.74, which is lower than the nominal value of 1:1. It's also lower than the authentic Pd/Mo ratio obtained by ICP-OES value of 0.86. Considering XPS is a very surface sensitive technique, while the ICP-OES measures the bulk element concentration, it is concluded that Pd and Mo are well dispersed on the surface. The dispersion of Mo is better than Pd. Spectroscopy studies of the PdMo catalysts are summarized in Fig. 4 . The UV-Vis spectra of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 4a. It is found that the PdMo/SiO2 and Mo/SiO2 catalysts show absorption bands in the UV region. In the spectra of Mo/SiO2 there are three bands at 204, 255, 310 nm, respectively. These peaks were attributed to the characteristic peaks of Mo6+ [41–43]. Similar results were obtained with PdMo/SiO2 samples. Besides, the spectra of Pd/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 show a broad peaks in the range of 400-500 nm associated with the d-d transition of Pd [44]. Raman spectroscopy was carried out to explore the structure of Mo on support (Fig. 4b). As a reference, the Raman spectrum of the bare SiO2 support is shown in Fig. S7. A set of Raman band at 455, 800, 980 cm−1 is confirmed for the SiO2 support. As to the catalysts, PdMo/SiO2 and Mo/SiO2 show Raman bands at 820 and 993 cm−1 assigned to MoO3 [45]. Besides, the band at 993 cm−1 is attributed to dioxo (Si-O)2Mo(=O)2 [46,47]. The O-Mo-O bending mode of the MoO3 was also observed at 340 cm−1 for both Mo supported catalysts. Therefore, a corresponding structure of Mo is proposed as Fig. 4d to illustrate the Mo species are highly dispersed on the surface of the bimetallic catalyst. The electronic state of Pd in the catalysts was investigated by diffusive reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectrum by using CO as the probe molecules (DRIFT-CO). Generally speaking, a molecule CO could adsorb on Pd surface via a back-donating bond with electron transfer from CO to the empty orbital of Pd. The more electron density transfers from CO to Pd atom(s), the lower wavenumber of adsorbed CO could be observed in DRIFT spectrum. As shown in Fig. 4c, two peaks in 1980 cm−1 and 1940 cm−1 are observed in Pd/SiO2 catalyst, which were assigned to CO adsorbed on continuous packed Pd-Pd atoms under bridge mode [48,49]. Moreover, another peak at 2086 cm−1 assigned to linearly chemisorbed CO on a Pd0 atom is also observed [48,49]. Therefore, the DRIFT-CO spectrum of Pd/SiO2 catalyst follows a typical pattern for metallic Pd nanoparticles. However, the DRIFT-CO spectra for the Mo/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 catalysts only exhibit a flat baseline (red and black lines, Fig. 4c), indicating the absence of the atom that could adsorb CO on the surface of the catalysts. Thus, it is concluded that Mo of the Mo/SiO2 catalyst could not adsorb CO. Moreover, Mo species of the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst also prevent the Pd atoms from adsorbing CO. In other words, the adsorption behavior of Pd in the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is greatly changed by Mo. 3.3 In-situ XAS studies on the synergy of the PdMo catalyst The in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was implemented to explore the coordination environment and chemical state of Pd and Mo in the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst under HDO conditions. The in-situ XAS spectrum will be discussed from the aspects of X-ray near edge structure (XANES), Fourier transformed extend X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) and wavelet transformed EXAFS (WT-EXAFS) in the following content. The spectra of Mo K edge and Pd K edge of the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst were collected upon reduction at 150°C, and under HDO reaction conditions including 150 °C and 250 °C. As concluded in Section 3.1, the structure of the bimetallic catalyst under HDO reactive condition at 250 °C is the major goal of the in-situ XAS study. To reveal the electronic state of Mo in the catalyst, the in-situ XANES spectra of Mo K-edge for PdMo/SiO2 catalyst are summarized in Fig. 5 a, including the catalyst as prepared (RT), reduced at 150 °C and under HDO conditions at 150 °C and 250 °C, respectively. The spectrum of Mo foil is also plotted as the reference. The XANES of the fresh catalyst follows a typical MoO3 pattern (PdMo/SiO2-RT, black line). A shoulder is clearly observed at the edge with the energy of 20012 eV, suggesting the Mo is in the chemical state of Mo6+ [50–52]. Moreover, the catalyst upon reduction and under HDO at 150°C exhibits the same XANES pattern. Thus, the electronic state of Mo during reduction and HDO at 150 °C remains the same to the fresh catalyst. As the temperature of HDO increases to 250 °C, a change is clearly observed in the XANES pattern as shown by the green line in the Fig. 5a. The shoulder at the edge disappears. Therefore, the Mo6+ in the catalyst was partially reduced by H2 to Mo4+ under HDO temperature of 250 °C [50,53]. This change is attributed to the presence of palladium in the bimetallic catalyst, which could decrease the reduction temperature of MoO3 as suggested by H2-TPR. The reduction temperature of Mo is lower than that of Mo/SiO2 catalyst due to the synergistic effect between Pd and Mo. The in-situ XANES of Pd K-edge of PdMo/SiO2 catalysts are showed in Fig. 5b. The spectrum of a Pd foil is plotted as the reference. The XANES spectrum of the fresh catalyst follows the characteristic features of cationic Pd. Upon reduction at 150 °C, Pd is reduced as evidenced by the downshift of the edge. Moreover, HDO condition at 150 and 250 °C further reduce Pd. The reduction progress of Pd is monitored on line by in-situ XANES. Above results are consistent with H2-TPR and XRD as discussed earlier. To demonstrate the coordination environment of Mo and Pd atoms, the FT-EXAFS of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst at different conditions were shown in Fig. 6 . All the spectra are plotted and discussed without phase correction unless otherwise noticed. The EXAFS of Mo K edge of PdMo/SiO2 as prepared (labeled as RT) exhibit a major coordination pathway in 1-2 Å, which is assigned to Mo-O bond [50,51]. Similar pattern is also found for the catalyst upon reduction and under HDO at 150 °C. This trend is consistent with the in-situ XANES as described in Fig. 5a. However, the amplitude of the Mo-O path decreases and shift to larger radial under HDO at 250 °C, suggesting the changes of Mo-O coordination under HDO condition. Moreover, a new peak is found at 2.2 Å, which is assigned to the formation of Mo-Pd pathway [14]. The coordination environment of Mo under HDO at 250°C is resolved by the data fitting as shown in Fig. S8 and Table S5. The coordination number (CN) of the nearest Mo-O pathway is fitted by two kinds of Mo-O bonds, which is 1.72 and 2.06 Å, respectively. The Mo-O bond of 1.72 Å is interpreted as Mo=O bond, while that of 2.06 Å is interpreted as Mo-O bond as shown in Fig. 4d. The CN of Mo-O and Mo=O are consistent with the spectroscopy results. The Mo-Pd path suggests the formation of Mo-Pd bond under HDO reaction at 250°C. The Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra of Pd K-edge are showed in Fig. 6b. In the as prepared catalyst, a major coordination pathway of Pd-O is observed. However, the Pd-O pathway disappears and then a new peak at 2.5 Å is found upon reduction and HDO conditions. The new peak is assigned to Pd-Pd and mixed with Pd-Mo coordination (see the fitting trial in Fig. S9 and Table S6). However, conclusive distinguishing and analysis for the Pd-Pd and Pd-Mo coordination pathways is a challenge by FT-EXAFS. The reason is that the atomic number of Mo (42) and Pd (46) are very close. Therefore, it is hard to observe an independent coordination peak of Pd-Mo coordination in the FT-EXAFS of Pd K edge. Wavelet transformation of EXAFS spectrum has attracting rising attention in recent decades for its capacity in distinguish the scattering (coordination) atoms with similar atomic number [24,25,54]. Here, the EXAFS spectra of Mo and Pd K edge are obtained to identify the Pd-Mo coordination pathway in the catalyst. The evolution of the Mo and Pd K edge is illustrated in the form of contour plots in Fig. 7 . The WT-transformed plots of Mo and Pd foils are also presented as the references. Generally, the maximum points with deep red in the contour plots suggest coordination pathway. Each maximum point in the contour plot belongs to a set of coordinator of (K, R), whereas the K is the function to the atomic number while R is the radial distance before phase correction. Therefore, the value of K is an indicator to distinguish the scattering atoms at the similar radial distance [24,25,54]. Due to the difference of atomic number of Pd (46) and Mo (42), a maximum point in contour plot associated with Pd is expected to show up at the larger K value than that of Mo. In other words, a maximum in contour plot resulted by the scattering atom of Pd shows a peak on the right side of that by Mo. As presented in Fig. 7a, the WT spectra of Mo K edge of the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst show a broad coordination peak, which is assigned to the Mo-O coordination path. The similarly of these spectra at fresh, upon reduction and under HDO at 150 °C suggests the coordination environment of Mo does not change. However, the contour plot changes significantly under HDO at 250 °C. A new peak marked with black arrow is observed. The K value of the new peak is at 10, which is higher than that of Mo-Mo coordination obtained from the Mo foil. Therefore, this new peak is confirmed as the Mo-Pd coordination pathway. The WT plots of Pd K edge also support the formation of Pd-Mo pathway as shown in Fig. 7b. The K value of the Pd-Pd coordination of the Pd foil, PdMo/SiO2 catalyst upon reduction is about 10, which is resulted by the Pd-Pd coordination. The center of the maximum of the catalyst under HDO at 250 °C moves to K=9, suggesting the contribution from Pd-Mo pathway. Therefore, the formation of Pd-Mo coordination pathway is confirmed by WT-EXAFS data again. From the in-situ XAS data the unique Pd-Mo bond structure is not observed under reduction pretreatment or under HDO at 150°C. It is only observed at HDO under 250°C, which is in line with the outstanding catalytic performance in Fig. 1. Thus, the Pd-Mo structure formed under HDO condition at 250°C is proposed as one of the key findings in this work. 3.4 Insights on the synergistic effect of PdMo catalyst The correlation between catalyst structure and activity is the core concept in heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, the synergistic effect in the PdMo bimetallic catalyst was firstly studied by the HDO reaction of anisole, a biomass-derived molecule. The HDO activity of bimetallic PdMo catalyst is superior to that of Pd/SiO2 or Mo/SiO2 in terms of anisole conversion, HDO selectivity and stability. The PdMo/SiO2 catalyst prefers to HDO selectivity while the hydrogenation is favored on Pd/SiO2 catalyst. Moreover, the stability of PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is much better than that of Pd/SiO2 (Figs. S1 and 1a). Therefore, the interplay between Pd and Mo contributes the catalytic performance from these aspects. The origination of the synergistic effect was explored from the comprehensive investigation on the PdMo bimetallic catalyst. Despite the Pd nanoparticles are the major active sites for the conversion of anisole, the presence of Mo promoter is predominant for the HDO catalyst. The crystalline of Pd nanoparticles in the PdMo/SiO2 is poorer than that of Pd/SiO2. Moreover, the redox and adsorption properties of Pd in PdMo/SiO2 catalyst is also influenced by Mo, and vice versa. The interaction from Pd to Mo is observed for the electron transfer from XPS. Based on the spectroscopy studies, it's proposed that Mo are highly dispersed on the catalyst, covering the Pd sites and dispersed on SiO2. Nevertheless, in-situ XAS studies reveal that the formation of Pd-Mo bond only under HDO conditions at 250°C. Therefore, the electronic state and coordination state of Pd are greatly impacted by the Mo, which further results in the enhanced HDO activity. A scheme of the synergistic effect between Pd and Mo is sketched as Scheme 1 . In the conventional reaction pathway on Pd nanoparticles catalyst, the molecule anisole adsorbed on metallic Pd in a flat geometry [1–3]. As the result, H2 dissociated on Pd to form hydrogen atoms facilely. Then aromatic ring is hydrogenated easily. In other word, hydrogenation is favored over Pd/SiO2 catalyst. As it is investigated in this work, the strong interaction between Mo and Pd changes the adsorption geometry of molecule anisole due to the steric effect and electron effect as evidenced by the XPS, DRIFT-CO, Raman and in-situ XAS results. The molecule anisole is proposed to be adsorbed on the catalyst via oxygen atoms, which allows the C-O bond cleavage at the mild reaction temperatures. 4 Conclusion Pd/SiO2, Mo/SiO2 and PdMo/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst were investigated for the hydrodeoxygenation of a biomass derived molecule, anisole. The synergistic effect in HDO performance is confirmed in the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst for high conversion, enhanced HDO selectivity and better stability. Comprehensive characterization techniques including TEM, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR reveal the interaction between Mo and Pd in the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst. Despite Mo is not catalytic active for HDO, its presence still changes the crystalline, electronic state, redox properties and adsorption behavior of the Pd catalytic sites. Moreover, the chemical state and coordination state evolution of Pd and Mo are revealed by in-situ XAS spectrum including XANES, FT-EXAFS, and WT-EXAFS. The formation of Pd-Mo coordination pathway is confirmed under HDO reaction condition at 250 °C, which is the authentic structure for the HDO catalytic activity. Therefore, this work brings new insights to understand the synergistic effect of bimetallic catalyst in HDO, and sheds a light on the atomic structure of bimetallic catalyst during catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic catalyst is a major group of the heterogeneous catalysts which has been widely investigated for many important catalytic processes such as biomass upgrading. The synergistic effect between two transition metal of bimetallic catalyst plays a vital role to promote catalytic performance. In this work, the Pd-Mo bimetallic catalysts were investigated for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of a biomass-derived molecule, anisole. The synergistic effect was confirmed in the Pd-Mo bimetallic catalyst. The correlated structure features of the Pd and Mo sites during catalysis have been revealed to understand the synergistic effect. It is found that the Mo species are partially reduced and cover around Pd nanoparticles. As the results, the crystalline status, redox properties, electron state and adsorption behaviors of Pd species are greatly influenced by Mo species. Moreover, the formation of Pd-Mo bond is directly observed by in-situ X-ray absorption spectrum. This work brings new insights to understand the structure origination for the synergistic effect in bimetallic catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ studies on the synergistic effect of Pd-Mo bimetallic catalyst for anisole hydrodeoxygenation
